history.content:
Recruiting + 61C + 70 + C8 + breadth will ruin your semester. However, it's still doable if you have strong ability to manage your time. If you don't have such confidence, then a great way to prepare for this (i.e. reduce your workload in semester) is to skim through the 70 and/or data 8 material during the summer. The martial for these two classes are public.

if you are taking data 8 for prep of Data 100 ONLY, I personally believe it's ok to skip Data 8 by having CS 61A + CS 61B + 70 (but the workload for data 100 will be slightly higher). (edit: see below, thanks for correcting me)

_________________________________________________________

@above anon, Data 8 is a hard prereq for Data 100 in Fall 18.

children.subject:
I'd say, like 2 units, but again it depends on how much time you put into it. I do not understand why people hype recruiting to be such a heavy time constraint on your schedule.

You can apply for the jobs during your free time.

Prepare for technical interviews in your free time as well, but the best thing to do would be to prep over summer.

But the rest, (forgive my bitterness) it depends on how competitive you are as a candidate and how many interview invitations you get. Most people without prior internship experience do not get that many offers/interview requests (sorry for breaking it to you again, but it is the truth). This does mean you have to work extra hard to get the few opportunities that are available, but I wouldn't say its as time consuming as a class. Moreover, I strongly feel that most recruiting actually happens in the spring, not fall. Most companies hiring in the fall are the among the big ones including the Big4 and to be honest, it is hard to get their attention unless you are an exceptional candidate. Again, I apologize for my pessimism but this is what I experienced and seen my friends experience..

How much work would you say recruiting is? (As you can see I'm pretty new at this lol)

I know there's prepping for interviews, reaching out/filling out applications, and possibly traveling for onsite interviews. Anything else I'm missing?

Basically if recruiting were a class how many units would it be?

history.content:
How's this schedule for next fall? LSCS incoming sophomore, still need to declare. Did well in 61A and doing well in B so I just need a B- or above in 70 probably. I might also want to get into recruiting and/or get more involved on campus, whether that means clubs or a work-study job.

For those who've had similar paths as me and did this schedule (or not), how is this? Will I be miserable and drowning in work for 4 months or will I pull through?
history.subject: 61C + 70 + Data 8 + easy breadth
